dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old Packard coup–π pulls up to a roadside gas pump. Two men get out and stretch their legs. The older man, Charli Burns, a balding, desiccated man in his mid-forties, sham toward the bar across the street. Eddie Felson remains be to speak to the attendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I got a little grease in  this lining here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Well, it will take me about  thirty minutes to check it. You want  me to fill her up too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You better check the oil too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie leaves the car parked at the gas station and heads the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armstead's is a typical small town pool hall. It has a ba a short order counter, a skee-ball machine, and pool tabl for small, friendly games. The few people in Armstead's t day are not playing; they sit and read the papers. Charli and Eddie are at the bar, drinking straight bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys just passing through?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pittsburgh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comin' in or goin' out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' in. We got a sales convention.  Gotta be there tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you guys sell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Druggist supplies. Buster here is  gonna get an award. (Eddie scoffs, as if  embarrassed) No, he sold seventeen thousand bucks'  worth of stuff last month. Fastest  boy in the territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Fastest and the bestest... Hey,  give us another round, will ya? One  for him, one for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Sure is a hot day for driving.  Late afternoon is better. You guys  have plenty of time. Make Pittsburgh  in two, maybe three hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Hey, he's right! (eyes the unused pool  table) Whaddya say, Charlie, huh? Play a  little pool? Wait out the heat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) It's gonna cost ya money. It always  does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, stop stalling. Grab  yourself a cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie rises from his barstool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Good thing he can afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is already at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Keep 'em coming, will ya, friend?   J. T. S. Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie joins Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game is in mid-progress. It's Eddie's shot. He downs bourbon, weaves a bit, bends over the table, and awkwardl pokes at the white cue ball with his stick, missing an ea shot. Several more townspeople have come in from the stre and are following the play. The bartender refills the gla as soon as they are emptied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You miss again, you lose again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the bar) What's the kid in hock for so far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About sixty, seventy bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (racking the balls,  to Charlie) Next game, ten bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Nice lookin' boy. Clean-cut. Too bad  he can't hold his liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two balls lay side by side on the table. Eddie peers at t trying to figure his shot, blinking his eyes to focus bet Some of the onlookers seem skeptical. But Eddie pats the  corner pocket confidently, leans over, and raps out his s The ball banks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made it, boy! I finally made it!  C'mon, pay up. Pay up, sucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pounds his pal Charlie on the shoulder and collapses i a nearby chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to take up crap shooting.  Talk about luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luck! Whaddya mean, luck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. You couldn't  make that shot again in a million  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't, huh? Okay. Go ahead. Set  'em up the way they were before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Set 'em up the way they  were before. Bet ya twenty bucks.  Make that shot just the way I made  it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody can make that shot and you  know it. Not even a lucky lush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stung, Eddie lies across the table and sets them up himse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that? (to the bystanders) Hm? Is that the way they were before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) C'mon, put it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They toss their money on the table, and Eddie shoots, but his shot is too hard and his ball leaps over the side of table. The bartender cannot contain his staccato laughter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set 'em up again... C'mon, set 'em  up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting up his cue) You're drunk, boy. I'm not gonna bet  ya any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get back on the road. You gotta  be at that convention in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up the flagpole with the convention.  C'mon, Charlie. You're into me now.  I got my money on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie pauses, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... well, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a chump. Don't bet any more  money on that damn fool shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Well, now... I mean, you figure I'm  a little drunk, and I'm loaded on  the hip, and you just want in, real  friendly, while the money's still  floating, huh? Okay... Go ahead. Set  'em up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheepishly, the bartender replaces the balls in their ori positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you want some easy money,  huh? Here's a hundred and five  dollars. That's one week's commission.  Now you want to take the whole thing,  and then you get a crack at your  easy money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take a piece of that action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (viciously) No. I want him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it out of the till.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eddie) I'll meet you in the car, chump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie chalks up his cue, waiting impatiently for the bart to return with the money from the cash register. Then he  downs his drink and quickly strokes out his shot, the bal banking crisply and directly into the corner pocket. Ther is a cocky leer on his face as he reaches for the dollar  bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door of the Packard coupe slams shut. Eddie Felson ho up his stuffed billfold for his pal, Charlie Burns, to se He tosses it on the seat beside him and turns on the igni

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Henry, the elderly Negro janitor, draws up the Venetian b to let the early morning light flood into AMES POOL HALL. Henry is the janitor of Ames, the sexton of this immense, shabby cathedral of pool, in which the pews are pool tabl covered with oilcloth slipcovers and the great vault of a room is lit by brass-and-globe chandeliers. Henry ambles  through Ames righting overturned ashtrays and replacing  yesterday's abandoned cue sticks. The cashier enters. He  looks at his watch, then checks his time against that of clock on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry nods, then steps up on a stool to fix the minute ha of the clock. It now stands at ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is twelve-thirty when Eddie Felson and Charlie Burns f enter into Ames. Only one table is in use; the hall is em In Eddie's hand is his leather cue case. They stand befor the swinging doors and look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, like a church. Church of the  Good Hustler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks more like a morgue to me. Those  pool tables are the slabs they lay  the stiffs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be alive when I get out, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They saunter over to the cashier's cage. A sign on the br bar reads NO GAMBLING ALLOWED...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's arrival is noted by Big John and Preacher, a gamb and an addict, who hang out at Ames at all hours, waiting for action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the cashier) No bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with some annoyance) No bar, no pinball machines, no  bowling alleys. Just pool. Nothing  else. This is Ames, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie takes his cue ball from the cashier's cage and head for a table. As he passes Charlie, he mimics the cashier wickedly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Ames, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two go to a table. Eddie selects a house cue, then ro it over the table top to test the roll. He seems pleased. runs his hand over the green felt as if he were caressing it. His last test is to sweep the cue ball into the corne pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice clean pocket drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie takes some balls out of the return box and throws t on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chalks his cue) How much am I gonna win tonight? Hm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie doesn't reply. But Big John and Preacher lean for in their chairs to listen in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten grand. I'm gonna win ten grand  in one night. (Charlie stares at  him) ...Well, who's gonna beat me? C'mon,  Charlie, who's gonna beat me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Okay. Nobody can beat you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten grand! I mean, what other poolroom  is there in the country where a guy  can walk out with ten grand in one  night? Jeez, you know, I can remember  hustling an old man for a dime a  game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big John, stubbly cigar between his fingers, drifts over their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eddie, off Big  John) You got company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching Eddie) You looking for action?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. You want to play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Hell, no! You Eddie Felson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your game? What do you shoot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You name it, we shoot it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, friend, I'm not trying to  hustle. I don't never hustle people  that walk into poolrooms with leather  satchels. Don't try to hustle me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm Eddie Felson. I shoot  straight pool. You got any straight  pool shooters in this here poolroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of straight pool game you  like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The expensive kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come up here to play straight pool  with Minnesota Fats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want some free advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts, sourly) How much'll it cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to Charlie) Who are you -- his manager, his  friend, his stooge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) You well-heeled, partner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home. Take your boy and go home.  Fats don't need your money, there's  no way you can beat him. Nobody's  beat him in fifteen years. He's the  best in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that wrong, mister. I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I told you what I wanted about  Minnesota Fats. You just go ahead  and play him, friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me where I can find him,  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comes right in this poolroom every  night, eight o'clock on the nose.  Just stay where you are. He'll find  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Big John walks off, Eddie smiles at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight sharp. A departing customer holds the door for an  incoming one: Minnesota Fats. Heads turn when he makes his punctual  appearance. Fats' clothes reflect his high station at Ames Pool Hall: gray felt bowler hat, and an expensive, tailored overcoat with a carnation in its lapel and two silk handkerchiefs  peeking up from its breast pocket. He moves like a sultan through the room, past Big John, w eyes dip significantly, and over to the coat rack, where  Henry respectfully takes his coat and hat. The buzzard-li eyes of the cashier direct his gaze toward Eddie's table. Fats withdraws a cigarette from his gold case, then casua strolls toward Eddie's table standing apart and quietly  observing the sharp, precise movements of his prospective opponent. Even though Ames is filled with players, there little noise other than the clicking of pool balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shoot a good stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Gee, you shoot straight  pool, mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now and then. You know how it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) You're, uh, you're Minnesota Fats,  aren't you? You know, uh, they say  Minnesota Fats is the best in the  country out where I come from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a fact?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, boy, they, heh, they say  that old Fats just shoots the eyes  right off them balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California. Oakland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: California? Is your name Felson?  Eddie Felson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you've been looking for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's right, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big John! You think this boy is a  hustler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats and Eddie regard each other with amusement, sharing private joke of pool hustlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like to gamble, Eddie? Gamble  money on pool games?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats, let's you and I shoot a game  of straight pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you shoot big-time pool, Fats.  I mean, that's what everybody says,  you shoot big-time pool. Let's make  it two hundred dollars a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I know why they call you Fast  Eddie. Eddie, you talk my kind of  talk... (moving to the main  table) Sausage! Rack 'em up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his command, Ames comes to life. Players drag their ch across the floor and position them around the main table. Eddie, hand to his mouth, realizes that the big moment ha arrived and beckons to Charlie for his leather cue case. uniformed maids withdraw the cover off the green felt top and Sausage, the racker, begins to bang the balls into th wooden racking triangle. Fats is in the washroom, scrubbing his hands and nails. E stands and screws together his inlaid, ivory-pointed cue Fats dries his hands. He and Fats eye one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast and loose, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the gut, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel tight -- but good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry helps Fats on with his coat. Sausage finishes racki Fats carefully extends his palms so that Henry may sprink on some talcum powder. They are ready to start. Fats,  immaculate in jacket and tie, tosses a wad of bills -- hi stake money -- onto the table. Charlie does the same, cou the bills out one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off the cash) Willie, hang onto that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie takes the money. Two balls are rolled to the end o the table, and Fats and Eddie, like two duelers, prepare shoot for the break. In the silence of the room, they bend over their cues and softly stroke out their shots. The balls roll down the ta bank off the far shoulder, and slowly return toward the t players. Fats' ball hits the closer shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The balls are returned and Eddie makes his break shot, a  glancing blow that leaves the pack of balls nearly intact and the white cue ball lying far away at the end of the t Eddie looks up, with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't leave you much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats walks around the table and peers at the balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) You left enough... six in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Placing his cigarette on the wooden rim of the table, Fat rams the cue ball into the pack, dropping the six ball in the pocket. The table is now his. Eddie sits down unhappi Fats plays quickly, moving from shot to shot with studied authority, his eyes and hands working fluidly together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen in the corner... (shot goes in) Ace in the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot goes in. As Eddie watches, the prancing, elegant Fats maneuvers around the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight. (shot goes in) Ten... (shot goes in) Eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers, to Charlie) Boy, he is great! Jeez, that old fat  man. Look at the way he moves. Like  a dancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve. Cross side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Fats' bejeweled fingers curl around the cue stick, the stick then darting out to send a ball caroming off a bank and into a side pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And them fingers, them chubby fingers.  And that stroke. It's like he's, uh,  like he's playing a violin or  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine ball. (shot goes in) Three ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats keeps sinking shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is eleven o'clock. Eddie is up. The crowd at Ames sits stolidly in their seats, watching each player, each move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot goes in and he lines up another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross-corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot is a difficult one involving a combination of ba As it rolls in, the crowd breaks into applause, and Fats  bangs the butt of his cue stick on the floor to show his  appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high angle of the table. Fats plays defensively, playin safety, leaving Eddie with little to shoot at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Eddie does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats peers at the pack of balls huddled together, then po to one that lies in the middle of the pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven ball in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big John looks around -- the shot seems impossible. Fats  slams the cue ball into the pack. The balls carom outward all directions. Only the seven rolls slowly into the corn pocket. Eddie slumps back in his seat as the crowd applau

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is twelve o'clock, and Fats dominates the play. As he  calls out the litany of his shots, we see, superimposed o his hands and his face and the sound of socking pool ball the spectators, stupefied by the action; Charlie, swallow hard; Eddie, looking on, waiting to play; and the bills  endlessly unfolding out of Charlie's hands and floating o the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-thirty and Fats is still shooting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ace in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot rolls in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (darkly, to Eddie) Quit. He's too good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, I'm gonna take him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You miss? (goes to the table  and chalks his cue) Well, you don't leave much when you  miss, do you, fat man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from his seat) That's what the game's all about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm hm... Two ball, side pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot goes in. Fats pounds his stick on the floor. No else makes a noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I gotta hunch, fat man. I  gotta hunch it's me from here on  in... One ball, corner pocket. (shot goes in) I mean, that ever happen to you?  When all of a sudden you feel like  you can't miss? I dreamed about this  game, fat man. I dreamed about this  game every night on the road... five  ball... (shot goes in) You know, this is my table, man. I  own it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats allows a perfunctory bow of his head, a courtly gest to Eddie's manager. Charlie looks away, avoiding his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is two-thirty. Now it's Eddie's voice we hear calling the shots. He circles the table, a proud, cocky smile on his face, a superimposed over his movements we see the spectators, hu up in their chairs, and Fats' face, glowering, hostile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The applause grows louder as the balls keep spinning towa the pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Game!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie beams with pride and excitement as he accepts the  acclamation of the sharks at Ames. He slaps down the chal and returns to his seat. It is almost four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay the man again, Fats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats draws himself slowly out of his chair and hands the  money to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Hey, how much are we ahead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Approximately? One thousand bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats, let's you and I shoot a game  of pool for a thousand dollars a  game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats hesitates for a moment, then reaches in his pocket f some bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preach! Go down and get me some White  Tavern whisky, a glass, and some  ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preacher! Go on down and get me some  bourbon. J. T. S. Brown. No ice, no  glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preach... get it at Johnny's. (to Eddie) You got a bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand up, remove their jackets, and prepare to play  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Preacher opens the door to the back room, clutching a  paper bag filled with bottles to his chest, we see six me seated around a table, playing poker. Preacher approaches one of them and whispers something hurriedly in his ear. man is Bert Gordon. Except for his dark glasses, he might pass for a conservative businessman out for an evening wi the boys, sipping milk instead of alcohol to soothe an ul He nods to Preacher who then leaves. Bert appears thought for a moment. He rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cash me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert sips his milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A floor full of cigarette butts surround Charlie's chair. Charlie crushes out another on the floor and immediately  reaches for more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two in the corner. (shot goes in) Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot goes in. Eddie drains the last drips from his bo of bourbon, then looks jauntily at Bert, who now sits qui in a chair, watching them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ace in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He misses. Eddie squirms out of his seat, eager to play,  eager to go on winning. Bert sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two ball, side pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot goes in. Fats opens a fresh bottle of whisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game goes on. The hands of the clock on the wall spin around toward eight in the morning. Ames is empty now, ex for the players and the employees. Only the voice of Saus is heard, signaling the end of a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Fats bends over to shoot, Henry draws the Venetian bli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you cut that sunshine out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert holds a hand to his temple, unnerved by Fats'  discomposure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a break in the action. Fats and Eddie eye each o coldly, Fats with his glass in his hand, Eddie with his  bottle. Eddie takes a swig and returns to the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert reaches forward to hand Charlie more money. Bert rep the billfold in his coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, weary now, his hands resting on the table, looks u at the cool, impassive face of Bert Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name's Gordon. Bert Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister. You been sittin' in that  spot for hours. Would you mind moving?  It bothers me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert rises, moves his chair about six inches, and sits do again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie goes over to the water cooler for a drink while Fat doles out his losings on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) How much we got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven thousand four hundred, cash.  Here in my pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preacher, go on down and get me some  breakfast, will ya? Egg sandwich and  a cup of coffee. You want something,  Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute. You're coming  with me. You're gonna eat breakfast  at the hotel. Pool game is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it isn't, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pool game is over when Fats says  it's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted ten thousand? You got ten  thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, get with it, will ya, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get with what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't see it, can you, Charlie?  I mean, you've never been able to  see it. I came after him. And I'm  gonna get him. I'm goin' with him  all the way. The pool game is not  over until Minnesota Fats says it's  over. Is it over, Fats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands before Fats and Bert Gordon, waiting for an ans Fats and Bert exchange glances but nothing is said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bert) I'm gonna beat him, mister. I beat  him all night and I'm gonna beat him  all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still no reply, no sign of giving in. Eddie starts to go  back to his chair, suddenly turns, a weary, clowning smil on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the best you ever seen, Fats.  I'm the best there is. Now even if  you beat me, I'm still the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie walks over to the water cooler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Fats) Stay with this kid. He's a loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to Charlie,  off Bert) What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie doesn't know and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's face buried in his lap as Charlie massages his ba Behind him, in the washroom, is Fats, washing his face an hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five hours, Eddie. Twenty- five hours you been playin' straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a drink, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you shut up... Just give me a  drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie gets Eddie a bottle. Bert and Henry watch Eddie  coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteen thousand, Eddie. We're ahead  eighteen thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drunken, exhausted Eddie nods, looks up at Bert, grins  maliciously, and takes a drink. Charlie starts to put awa Eddie's cue stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said this game was  over when Minnesota Fats said it  was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, it's over now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats emerges from the washroom, dries his hands, looks at Eddie and then at Bert who nods. Henry helps Fats into th jacket with the carnation still in the lapel. Eddie grins this. So does Bert. Fats opens his palms for the sprinkli of the talcum powder. Fats rubs his hands together, then  takes out his cigarette case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast Eddie, let's play some pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert smiles in appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie grabs the leather case out of Charlie's hands. Eddi rises and confronts Fats almost scornfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look beautiful, Fats. Just like  a baby... all pink, and powdered up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie looks down at his own dirty, disheveled shirt. He a a smiling Bert exchange glances. Eddie moves to put on hi jacket. Charlie confronts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to do, Eddie?  You beat him. You beat him bad. You  wanna kill yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are ya, chicken, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe that's it. I'm chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on home. Just leave me the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enraged) Charlie, boy, you better give me  that money. C'mon now, give it to  me. It's mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, here... (slaps money into  Eddie's hand) Be a damn fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie puts a bottle into the pocket of his jacket and ret to the table to screw together his cue stick. The sight o Fats makes him laugh again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you really look beautiful,  Fats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone stares at Eddie as he scratches his head, alone  with his private joke. Eddie abruptly tosses his cue case away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) I'll break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A worried Charlie picks up the case and stands by mutely, watching Eddie disintegrate. Eddie leans over to shoot, t turns away, laughing loudly to himself. Fats watches him, soberly, patiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high angle. Fats is shooting. No one is really watching any more. Eddie is asleep on a stool against a wall. Even Bert is  dozing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine ball... fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shots go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie. Wake up, Eddie... (Eddie awakens slowly) We lose again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie bangs his head against the wall. He knocks over a b as he tries to get up off the stool. The noise startles h Charlie watches sadly. Eddie gropes through his pockets a comes up with a few crumpled bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this all we got left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's all you got, that's all we  got left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats rises and tosses his cue on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie, give me the stake money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie gives him the stake money. Fats confronts Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats, I got about two hundred dollars  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Game's over, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats, look, I got about two hundred  dollars here. You can't run out on  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats steps by Eddie and heads for the coat rack, slapping the stake money into Bert's hand as he goes by. Bert retu the money to his billfold, wordlessly. The blinds are dra and the light strikes Eddie in the eyes, but still he stu after Fats, holding his money out before him, pleading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats, c'mon. C'mon. Hey, Fats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bangs against the corner of the table and falls onto t floor. Fats hears him go down and pauses, turning to see  Charlie rush to Eddie's side. After a moment, Fats contin on toward the door. Charlie slaps Eddie's cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie... Eddie... Eddie... Eddie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert, Sausage, Willie, Preach step around the body on the way out.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Eddie is lying on his bed staring at the ceiling, the cra of pool balls sounding in his head. He looks over at Char asleep in the next bed. He rolls out of bed and goes to t window. We see a neon sign flashing across the street. It reads AMES BILLIARDS. Then Eddie returns to his bed, leav the keys to the Packard and some money on the night table next to Charlie. He picks up his valise, his hanging bag, and his leather cue case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I'm sorry, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie goes toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eddie enters, carrying his bags, a few early morning  travelers -- some soldiers and a man in a Stetson hat --  pass him by. He has been up all night. He rubs his grimy  face, then heads for the door marked "Gentlemen."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a typical bus station washroom at that time of the  morning. The residue of a full day's traveling is in evid crumpled paper towels, cigarette butts, etc. Part of the  residue is a drunk who sits on the shoeshine seat, fast  asleep. Eddie looks at him, shaking his head. A wizened o attendant sits nearby. A sign on the wall reads IS THIS Y LUCKY DAY? Eddie laughs to himself, puts his hanging bag cue case on a chair, then turns to face his image in the  mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the attendant) Give me a towel, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attendant, whose every move seems to require a tremen effort, shuffles over and grabs a towel as Eddie removes jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the row of coin lockers in the waiting room is a sma lunch counter and several tables. At one table, facing th lockers, is a young woman, Sarah: a book is open before h and a cup of coffee, and an ashtray filled with cigarette butts. She looks up for an instant as Eddie appears. He n has on a clean shirt and is clean and freshly shaven. He  locks his bags in a locker. Her eyes return to the printe page. Moving toward the counter, Eddie notices Sarah. He  goes to the lunch counter, still looking at her. He sniff some wrapped sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie wanders over to a table next to Sarah's and sits do She ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long wait for a bus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns to her reading. Eddie keeps looking at her. H hair is brown, cut short, practically straight. Her lips pale and thin, and the bone structure of her face, althou delicate, is much in evidence. There is a suggestion of tired wakefulness, of self- sufficiency, about her. And a frank, open regard which ha nothing in it to imply flirtation -- or the lack of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you been waiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been waiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah goes back to reading. The waitress arrives to take  Eddie's order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the waitress) Just a cup of black coffee, please... (the waitress starts  to go) Hey, ma'am! Wait a minute! (to Sarah) Would you, uh, like another cup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Fine, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie holds up two fingers to the waitress, who departs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time does the bus leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What bus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wouldn't give us much time,  would it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Well, you're right. I guess it  wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffee comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making a toast) Hello and goodbye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie leans back against the wall and shuts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long pause) Have a nice trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips off to sleep. The waitress brings a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Eddie anxiously as she digs in her purse for the coins. She pays, collects her purse and book, and rises to leave Eddie doesn't stir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The public address system bleats over the noise of the cr luncheonette. The waitress leans over and slaps Eddie on shoulder. He wakes up with a cramped neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was paid for... by the lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar is nearly empty when Eddie comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Give me some bourbon. J. T. S. Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a chaser?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he looks around the bar he sees Sarah, alone at a back booth, sipping a highball. She seems amused by their  encounter. So does he. He takes his drink and joins her a the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? We already know each other's  secrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after he sits) Thanks for the, uh, for the breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two ships that pass in the night  should always buy each other  breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I buy you another drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls to the bartender) Hey, another one for me and another  one for the lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look different... More relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the lights. And the scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you didn't catch your bus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't waiting for a bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why go to the bus station?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same reason you went: at that hour  of the morning you haven't much  choice. Besides, I only live three  blocks from there. Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where you live: in a locker,  in a bus station. What's it like  living in a locker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cramped. (she smiles) You always drink like this, so early  in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always ask so many questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wake up and I can't sleep,  not without a drink. The bars don't  open until eight. Mack over there  has faith in me. When I'm broke, he  trusts me. Don't you trust me, Mack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm not broke, I usually have a  bottle in my room, in which case I  sleep very well indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk kind of funny, but I like  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to be an actress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What do you do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a college girl. Two days a week,  Tuesdays and Thursdays, I go to  college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look like a college girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the emancipated type. Real  emancipated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't mean that -- whatever  that means. I mean, you just don't  look young enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why go to college?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got nothing else to do on  Tuesdays and Thursdays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do on the other days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No more. I'm getting sleepy. (puts a scarf around  her head) Thank you very much, Mr...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie. The name is Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studies his face) The name should be Eddie. What should  my name be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Whatever you like it  to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it to be what it is. It's  Sarah. That's a biblical name. You  want to know its meaning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could always get us a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little alarmed) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifth of scotch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do, just step  out in the alley? Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'll take you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause as she tries to read his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie finishes his drink, rises, crosses to the bar, pays the bill, and returns to the booth. As they go out, Sarah stumbles, and he catches her by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. (smiling) I'm not drunk... (serious) I'm lame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie pauses a moment to register this as she limps off,  then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie goes into the liquor store. Sarah waits outside, st and uneasy. Then he comes out with the scotch and they walk off down street together. They walk slowly, with their eyes pointe straight ahead. He tries to ignore her halting gait. They pass under the awning of the neighborhood's elegant Paris restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she searches through her purse for her keys, he reache out and puts his hand on her shoulder. She closes her eye then draws back against the door, fearful, like a threate animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her head in his hands and kisses her. She respon but, as he holds her tighter, she starts to struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... please... please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes him away and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand there for a long moment: she looks away; he lo down at the floor. Then Eddie takes the bag of scotch and places it underneath her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. It's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves her there in the hall and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door opens. A hotel manager shows Eddie into a dingy, b furnished room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have this one for a buck and  a half a night, or seven bucks by  the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches in his pocket and pulls out some bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie removes his bags from the locker. The sight of the  lunch counter reminds him of Sarah. But the lunchroom is  empty; only the janitor is there, mopping up. Eddie picks his bags and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, on his way back to the hotel, stops at the same li store for a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters his room, puts down his bags and the liquor, an sits on his rusted brass bed. From his pocket he pulls ou the few crumpled bills he has left. He looks at the money shakes his head disgustedly, and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a friendly, neighborhood bar for business people an cocktail drinkers. Eddie walks casually by the pool table and over to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bottle of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns on his stool to watch the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, uh, mister? Hey, okay if I grab  a cue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you're Eddie Felson, aren't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, look, fella, I saw you playing  at Ames the other night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'll tell you what -- I'll play  you jack-up pool -- just keep one  hand in my pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning to his  game) Oh man, you're way out of our league.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie goes back to his bottle of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some bills drop on a ragged, beat-up pool table. Two men, dressed in work clothes, stand around looking disgruntled

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you stuck for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three. That's enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up the cash) Thanks... Can I, uh, buy you fellas  a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you shoot good. But you  also shoot lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding his head) Yeah. I shoot lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sits at a table, smoking, waiting. The paper bag wi the whisky is on the table. Sarah, dressed in a dark suit limps toward him. He mashes out his cigarette in the asht When he looks up, he sees Sarah standing nearby. She seem cold and suspicious as she limps toward the table. She pa and looks at him. They stare at one another for a long mo He gets up, puts his arm around her shoulder, and walks a with her. As they walk, she hesitantly puts an arm around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand reaches up to open the wooden shutters. As they op we see Eddie, in his underclothes, on the bed. Sarah, in robe, walks up and joins him in bed as they both peer out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to see what kind of a day  it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A day like any other. People come,  people go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him her cigarette. He starts to put on his  wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven o'clock... I'll be back later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you need a shave. You mustn't go  looking like that. There's a razor  and shaving cream in the bathroom.  Compliments of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say that for, Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know my name was Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lied. When I'm drunk I lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. So what's your name today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah. (pause) Eddie, look. I've got troubles, and  I think maybe you've got troubles.  Maybe it'd be better if we just leave  each other alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her again, this time on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got my things over at the hotel.  I'll bring them over later... (shifts position,  pulls her close) Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in his arms) I'm not sure... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you want to know? And  why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches out and closes the shutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah emerges from a neighborhood grocery store loaded do with a Cheese Doodles carton full of food. A woman runs o of the store to give her a parcel she left behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warmly) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prego.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She carries the carton across the street to her apartment house, quietly saying hello to a couple of neighbors alon the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah's apartment is a typical city studio apartment: one cluttered room for sleeping and eating, and a small  kitchenette. As Sarah knocks, Eddie is perched on the win sill. He goes to open the door. Sarah enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you been all day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At school. It's Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her schoolbooks out of the carton and takes her  purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were asleep when I left. I didn't  want to wake you. Did you go out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I went out for a couple of  hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She unloads liquor and canned goods from the carton, then goes to join Eddie by the window. Sarah takes a cigarette lighter out of her purse and hands it to Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off the lighter) Present...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I've been living here for  almost three years. Now in three  days it seems as if I know everybody.  When I pass people on the street I  want to stop and say, "Listen, I got  a fella."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strokes her hand) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, where do you go when you go  out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Museums... art galleries... concerts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, then she gets up and returns to the kitchenet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I believe you when you say you  go to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, are you kidding? See that book? (holds up a book) I've been trying to get through that  book ever since I first got here. I  haven't finished the first chapter. (off her bookcase) Did you read all them books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it all in your head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm sober. They get a little  mixed up when I'm drunk. Most of the  time they're mixed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Oh, stop talking about yourself like  you're a lush or something. I don't  like it. (genuinely concerned) Maybe you ought to go to a clinic,  get some treatments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting treatments right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes up behind her and puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your choice. I've got enough so  we won't have to go out of the house  till Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did all this stuff cost you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you've got money, you'll pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, c'mon, I wanna know. I wanna  keep score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bills are right here. You didn't  say what you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off the canned goods) Don't you ever cook anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eggs. How do you like them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cuts her hand opening a can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, cut my finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got something in my bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he rummages through the closet for his bag he pulls ou his leather cue case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, what's in that case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you opened it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, why should I? It's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a machine gun. This guy told me  when I came to the big city I'd have  to have a machine gun, so I bought  one. (bandages her finger) Where do you get the money? To pay  for all this? I mean the liquor, and  the groceries, and the rent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a rich old man who used to be  my lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss. Someone knocks on the door. Sarah goes to open it. We stay on Eddie, who examines the lighter in his han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters the room, awkwardly, toying with the rim of his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Charlie... (turns) C'mon in... (off Sarah) That's my girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) Hello, Eddie's girl... (to Eddie) I looked all over for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? How'd you find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eddie) Do you want me to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, stick around. (to Charlie) Can I get you something? Drink?  Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't want to be no bother to  nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't play it small, Charlie. It  don't look good on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you want me to play it? I'm  broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I... Sit down. (to Sarah) Would you get us a couple of drinks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to make the drinks. Charlie sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You walked out on me like that. No  goodbye, no nothing. Like a thief in  the dark. We were partners. We were  more than partners. (to Sarah) He was like a... like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, like a son. (to Sarah who brings  drinks) I've known this boy since he was  sixteen. The first time I saw him,  back in Oakland, I said, "This is a  talented boy. This is a smart boy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to me, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to come back on the road  with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aah! I've got no stomach for that  any more. I've had that kind of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of life have you got here?  Scufflin' around the small rooms,  picking up eight, ten bucks a day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll connect. I'll get you your money  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you figuring on going back to  Ames to play Minnesota Fats again?  Is that what's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never been out of it. I'm gonna beat  that fat man... with that curly hair,  and those diamond rings, and that  carnation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) This boy's crazy. They wiped the  floor with him. They beat his brains  out and he wants to go back. (to Eddie) What for? To take another beating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you you'd get your money back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) He thinks I care about the money. (to Eddie) I care about you. Do you care about  me, Eddie? We're together a long  time, night and day. So how do you  say goodbye? (rises) You gimme the car and a hundred bucks.  You think I care about the dough,  the car? I care about you. (to Sarah) This boy is the greatest pool hustler  you ever saw. A real high-class con  man. He can charm anybody into  anything. Did he ever tell you how  well we were doing on the road? We  had everything: we ate good, we slept  late, we had money to burn. Whisky,  dames... (apologetic, to Sarah) Excuse me... (to Eddie, off Sarah) I'll tell you what -- take her along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie leans up against the wall, listening. Sarah watches them both, curious, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what else: you don't  want to start right away, we won't  start right away. We'll get in the  car and drive down to Miami, get all  this crud out of your system, have a  few laughs, lie in the sun for a  couple of weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Eddie becomes tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. I'll raise the  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference where? I'll  raise it. (to Sarah) Is it all right if I have another  drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah turns to fix the drink. Eddie signals her to stay w she is. He moves forward, confronting Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hold out on me, Charlie?...  How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie doesn't answer, so Eddie snatches hold of his jac and shoves him back into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOW MUCH?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My twenty-five per cent. Approximately  fifteen hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you crumb. With that fifteen  hundred I coulda beat him. That's  all I needed, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, c'mon, just give me the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? To play Fats again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, to play Fats again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna come back on the road with  me, okay, the money's yours. But if  you wanna give it to Minnesota Fats...  nothing doing. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (viciously) You still don't see it, do you,  Charlie? You are nothing but a small- time Charlie. You'd love to keep me  hustling for you, huh? Wouldn't ya?  I mean, a couple more years with me,  scuffling around them little towns  and those back alleys. You might  make yourself enough to get a little  poolroom back in Oakland. Six tables  and a handbook on the side. Is that  when you say goodbye to me, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. That's what I want.  Poolroom with a little handbook on  the side. Getting old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay down and die by yourself. Don't  take me with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie walks off. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tear rolls down Sarah's cheek as she hears this. She st near the door, with her back to both of them. Charlie get up and moves toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the drink, Eddie's girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, her cheek wet, says nothing. Charlie puts on his h and leaves. Eddie empties his glass and slaps it on the shelf next to Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pours it out, saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy! Everybody, everybody wants a  piece of me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah hands Eddie his drink without looking him in the ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you gonna have one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pours herself a very stiff drink as Eddie moves about restlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he have to come back here  for anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah drinks her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She keeps drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still drinking, she turns to him. They embrace and kiss o another without putting down their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: The room is a mess and Sarah is drunk. She sits on her kn on the floor, pecking at the keys of her typewriter with finger. Her bottle and her glass are beside her. A bare- chested Eddie is in the kitchen behind her, tossing empty cans and bottles from the sink into a garbage bag. He  carelessly wipes the sink, then throws down the dishrag a goes to the closet, pulling out his leather case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. For a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reaching for the bottle, Sarah abruptly lurches forward o her typewriter, and knocks the bottle over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (atop the typewriter) Ohhhhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie quickly moves to help her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He helps her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't answer. Eddie stares at Sarah as she sways li on her knees, unmindful of her open robe. Eddie picks up bottle and sets it before her. Taking her ashtray, Eddie  rises, runs his hand through her hair for a moment, and t carries off the ashtray and empties it in the garbage bag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, still hopelessly drunk, is sprawled out on her bed futilely attempting to dial a telephone. Eddie, in a clea shirt and pants, watches her. He sets the bottle down nea the typewriter and notices the sheet of paper stuck in th typewriter's carriage. He bends down to read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up from the  phone) Oh, it's a story. A story I'm making  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She falls back on the bed. Eddie pulls the paper out of t carriage and reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it back to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this supposed to mean: "We  have a contract of depravity. All we  have to do is pull the blinds down."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't answer. He thinks for a moment, then angrily  crumples the paper in his hands and throws it at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write yourself another story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sardonic laugh) Well, what else have we got? We never  talk about anything. We stay here in  this room, and we drink, and we make  love. (sits up in bed) We're strangers. What happens when  the liquor and the money run out,  Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie gives her a look, then lowers his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told Charlie to lay down and  die. Will you say that to me too? (rises and stumbles  over to him) What happens, Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find yourself another rich  old lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right! And I'm sure you'll  help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie turns and slaps her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You waiting for me to cry? (stares at him coldly) You bum... You poolroom bum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eddie pushes through the glass doors to the front room Johnny's bar. He looks around at the unused pool tables,  then goes to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a bottle of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man in a business suit comes out of the back room and j him at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you make out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a couple of bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poker game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it open?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man looks to the bartender for his answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's open... (to the man) What'll you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie takes his beer to the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poker game is in progress. Four men are playing. One them is Bert Gordon. His glass of milk is beside him on t table. He takes note of Eddie's presence with a quick dar of his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a seat next to Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the limit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half and a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme ten bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the chips, then throws out another bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eddie) Cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cards are dealt Eddie steals a glance at the man h has come to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game is over. Bert is already in the front room. He s at a table with a drink, and watches Eddie pass him by on the way to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourbon. J. T. S. Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie looks at Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly, to Eddie) I'm buyin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you only drank milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only when I work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it. It's good for you. Besides,  you start drinking whisky gambling  and it gives you an excuse for losing.  That's something you don't need --  an excuse for losing. How did you  make out in the poker game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost twenty bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poker's not your game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You being cute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think there's a pool player  alive shoots better pool than I saw  you shoot the other night at Ames.  You got talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I got talent. So what beat me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah. Sure, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're damned right I'm sure.  Everybody's got talent. I got talent.  You think you can play big-money  straight pool, or poker, for forty  straight hours on nothing but talent?  You think they call Minnesota Fats  the best in the country just 'cause  he's got talent? Nah. Minnesota Fats's  got more character in one finger  than you got in your whole skinny  body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drank as much whisky as you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he knows how to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet he knows how. (sips his drink) You think that's a talent too, huh?  Knowin' how to drink whisky? You  think Minnesota Fats was born knowin'  how to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... What do I do now, lie  down on the floor and, uh, bow from  the ankles? What do I do, go home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I stay. Stay until I hustle up  enough to play Fats again. Maybe by  that time I'll develop myself some  character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amused, Bert gets up and joins Eddie at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe by that time you'll die of old  age. How much do you think you'll,  uh, need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, three thousand at least. He'll  start you off at five hundred a game --  he'll beat the pants off you. That's  the way he plays when he comes up  against a man who knows the way the  game is. He'll beat you flat four or  five games -- maybe more, depending  on how, uh... steady your nerves  are. But he might -- he just might  be a little scared of you, and that  could change things. But I wouldn't  count on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know? Huh? When nobody  knows that much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that big car parked out by the  fireplug on the way in? Well, that's  mine. I like that car. But I get a  new one every year because I make it  my business to know what guys like  you and Minnesota Fats are gonna do.  I made enough off of you the other  night to pay for it twice over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, you owe me another  drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert laughs and signals the bartender for another round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, is it all right if I get  personal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaddya been so far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, you're a born loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time in ten years I ever saw  Minnesota Fats hooked, really hooked.  But you let him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. I got drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, you got drunk. That's the best  excuse in the world for losing. No  trouble losing when you got a good  excuse. And winning! That can be  heavy on your back too. Like a monkey.  You drop that load too when you got  an excuse. All you gotta do is learn  to feel sorry for yourself. It's one  of the best indoor sports: feeling  sorry for yourself -- a sport enjoyed  by all, especially the born losers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slaps down his glass  and rises) Thanks for the drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Maybe I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the three thousand. Play Minnesota  Fats again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten reasons. Maybe fifteen. And also  there's something in it for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I figured that. How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy-five per cent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a -- that's a pretty big slice.  Who do you think you are, General  Motors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you think you're worth these  days? I'm puttin' up the money, I'm  puttin' up the time. For that I get  seventy-five per cent return on my  money -- if you win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I can lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw you do anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw me beat Minnesota Fats for  eighteen thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
