dialogues.text: Look, you wanna hustle pool, don't  you? This game isn't like football.  Nobody pays you for yardage. When  you hustle you keep score real simple.  The end of the game you count up  your money. That's how you find out  who's best. That's the only way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why back me then? Why not back  yourself? Go find yourself a big fat  poker game and get rich. You know  all the angles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm already rich. But I like action.  That's one thing I think you're good  for is action. Besides, like I say...  you got talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) Yeah, you already told me that. You  cut that slice down to bite-size and  maybe we can talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we don't talk. I don't make bad  bets. Seventy-five, twenty-five.  That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait. (beat) What are you gonna do about the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are places. I'll scuffle around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Word's out on you, Eddie. You walk  in the wrong kind of place and they'll  eat you alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, when did you adopt me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a friendly grin) I don't know when it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound of ship's horn. Eddie walks past the piers and  warehouses toward a small waterfront bar called Arthur's  Pool Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The atmosphere at Arthur's is stifling, oppressive. A few lonely drinkers, dock workers, sit stooped over their bee bottles at the bar. In the back is a pool table. As Eddie enters, we see two  burly men, cue sticks in hand, watching as a pale, skinny young man lines up his shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to young man) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange glances, sizing each other up. Then the you man puts in his shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing money on  the table) You lucky punk. I quit ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eddie) You want in, friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you playin' for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dollar on the five, two on the  nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll play you a couple. Just  for kicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie goes over to the rack and takes a cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the other players is putting away his cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess that does it for me  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brashly, to Eddie) You quittin' too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a pretty good player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much are you ahead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple of bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it's just you and me, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess it is, boy. Just you  and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna raise the bet? Two on the  five, five on the nine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, kid? I think maybe  you're a hustler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young man makes his break shot, slamming the nine int the pocket. He looks up at Eddie, grinning snidely. The other two men the losers, stand around, mutely following the play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want to quit,  friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly irked) Let's cut out the small stuff, huh?  Hundred dollar freeze-out. Ten games,  ten bucks a game, winner take all.  And then we'll see who quits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, friend. You're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulls out a coin) Call it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie tosses the coin on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie collects his coin while the young man racks up the  balls. Preparing to break, Eddie chalks his cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better not miss, friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savagely) I don't rattle, kid. But just for  that I'm gonna beat you flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rams the cue ball into the pack. The nine drops in.  Everyone is stunned, particularly the young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie has lost control of himself. He is shooting as he d at Ames, rapping in his shots with perfect control. He is completely oblivious to the glowering faces of the group men who have gathered around the table to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie makes a tough shot. The men exchange uneasy glances

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More tough shots: tricky combinations, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie finishes up with yet another combination shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's ten. You punk, you two-bit  punk. C'mon, pay up. A hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young man digs nervously into his jacket for the mone All eyes are on Eddie. The young man sets down his cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You quittin', friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm quittin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sensing what is about to happen, the young man pays up. H drops the cash on the table and leaves quickly. Then one the other men steps forward, a thick-fleshed, obscene-loo man named Turk. His mouth twists into a mock smile. As Ed looks about him at the circle of silent men, each one gla at him, his fury gives way to fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you're a pool shark, boy. A  real pool shark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, so's he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're better than he was. Much  better. (points to bills on  the table) There's your money, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie wipes his mouth with his sleeve and nervously backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's your money, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie tries to back off but there is nowhere to go, so he makes a casual movement toward the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the men grab Eddie and pin his arms. One man gr him around the throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonically, to the  men) Wait a minute! Let's give this boy  his money. (to Eddie) We always pay what we lose, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turk takes the bills from the table and stuffs them into  Eddie's breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eddie) We got no use for pool sharks around  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drag Eddie into the men's room and shove him up agai the ground-glass partition. We see his cheek pressed agai the glass, and the foggy silhouettes of the others behind him. Eddie, his mouth open, screams horribly. There is a  pause. He screams again. They let go of his arms and he s to the floor. The bartender turns and goes back to the ba in the front room. The ship's horn is heard again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah sits alone in the darkened room, dressed in her rob and slip, lost in a drunken half-sleep. There is a knock the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. It's Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the door and opens it. Her eyes are puffy, he face is covered with perspiration. She opens the door, th looks up to see him leaning against the wall, his arms tu into his chest, with one hand covering the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got beat up. They... (beat) They broke my thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah is stunned and moves to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes him in her arms. He starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they broke my thumbs. Broke my  thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah watches as Eddie, both hands now encased in plaster casts, tries to sleep. He tries to move his arms, as if t to defend himself. Sarah rises, joins him, and strokes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are seated at the breakfast table. Sarah pours him s coffee and he tries to bring the cup to his lips, but he  cannot manage it. Disgusted, he drops the cup on the floor and gets up from the table. Sarah bends down and patiently wipes up the spilled coffe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apartment is now clean and neat. And Sarah is sober. is at her table, typing, while Eddie stands at the window trying to reach over his shoulder to scratch his back. He comes over to the table and, with his mouth, picks a ciga out of the pack. He looks quickly at her, without asking  directly for the match. She lights it and, as she does, h glances at the sheet in the typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can read it, if you want to. (Eddie shrugs) You want to go out for a while? To a  movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pacing restlessly) You wanna drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly opening the  door) What's it so hot in here for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to unbutton his shirt and Sarah immediately get up to help. But he holds her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches him struggle with the button for a while then spread his arms in a gesture of helplessness. As she unbu his shirt for him, he takes her face in his hands and kis her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah and Eddie emerges from the doorway. It is a warm,  beautiful day, and Sarah has a basket with her. Eddie see happy to be out with her, almost as if he has forgotten t casts on his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop at a spot that overlooks the river and spread o a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie leans back on the grass and looks at Sarah. They bo seem easy and relaxed in the sunshine together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, do you think I'm a loser?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loser?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I met this guy -- Gordon, Bert  Gordon. He said I was. Born loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would he know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows. A lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did he tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm not sure. He said  there are people who want to lose,  who are always looking for an excuse  to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he do, this Bert Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a gambler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he a winner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he owns things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what makes a winner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what else does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it bother you? What he said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (after a pause) Yeah. It bothers me a lot. (pause) 'Cause, you see, twice, Sarah --  once at Ames with Minnesota Fats and  then again at Arthur's... (sits up) ...in that cheap, crummy poolroom...  Now, why'd I do it, Sarah? Why'd I  do it? I coulda beat that guy, I  coulda beat him cold. He never woulda  known. But I just had to show 'em, I  just had to show those creeps and  those punks what the game is like  when it's great, when it's really  great. You know, like anything can  be great -- anything can be great...  I don't care, bricklaying can be  great. If a guy knows. If he knows  what he's doing and why, and if he  can make it come off. I mean, when  I'm goin' -- when I'm really goin' --  I feel like... (beat) ...like a jockey must feel. He's  sittin' on his horse, he's got all  that speed and that power underneath  him, he's comin' into the stretch,  the pressure's on him -- and he knows --  just feels -- when to let it go, and  how much. 'Cause he's got everything  workin' for him -- timing, touch.  It's a great feeling, boy, it's a  real great feeling when you're right,  and you know you're right. It's like  all of a sudden I got oil in my arm.  Pool cue's part of me. You know,  it's a -- pool cue's got nerves in  it. It's a piece of wood -- it's got  nerves in it. You feel the roll of  those balls. You don't have to look.  You just know. Ya make shots that  nobody's ever made before. And you  play that game the way nobody's ever  played it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a loser, Eddie. You're a  winner. Some men never get to feel  that way about anything. I love you,  Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie lowers his eyes and leans back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, someday, Sarah, you're  gonna settle down. You're gonna marry  a college professor, and you're gonna  write a great book. Maybe about me,  huh? Fast Eddie Felson, hustler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need the words?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I need them very much. And if  you ever say them I'll never let you  take them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is about to knock on the door to Sarah's apartment. stops for a moment to look at his hands. The casts are of He knocks on the door with his wrist, as he would if he s had them on. When she opens the door he holds them up boy before her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You glad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses his hands.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JOHNNY'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Eddie flexes his fingers, then tries out a shot on one of Johnny's pool tables. He uses the simpler, open hand brid to support his cue. Bert Gordon enters, and watches him p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. How's business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, slow... Why the open hand bridge?  Something wrong with your hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues to shoot) Yeah. Had a little accident. A place  called Arthur's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. You seem to do all right that  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say my game is about twenty per  cent off. Maybe more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? Somebody step on your  hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Big creep. Broke my thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man named Turk Baker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know everybody, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody who can hurt me, everybody  who can help me. It pays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you oughta give me lessons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first match I got in mind for  you is in Louisville, Kentucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You name the place, boss. I'll be  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I told ya. My thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't mean the thumbs. You  already told me about the thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking about what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm not such a high-class piece  of property right now. And a twenty- five per cent slice of something big  is better than a hundred per cent  slice of nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Hey, get us a couple of drinks here,  will ya? J. T. S. Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert smiles at Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a quiet, elegant restaurant, one with soft piano mu and subdued lighting. Eddie and Sarah had walked past it first day they met. Eddie and Sarah enter. She has on new dress and Eddie, looking a little ill at ease, has on a s and tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. (digs into pocket and  hands him a bill) Give use a nice, quiet table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Right this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headwaiter seats them at a table. Eddie and Sarah exc smiles. A waiter approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a drink before dinner,  sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) Hey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherry. (to the waiter) Very old, very dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the waiter) Two. (the waiter leaves) Sherry?... Nice joint. You look very  pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly she breaks into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your tie. I never saw you wear one  before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touches the knot  self-consciously) First time for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter returns with the bottle of sherry and holds it out to Eddie for his approval. There is a long pause as E looks from the bottle to the waiter. Finally, Eddie reali he must respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. That's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter pours out the sherry as Eddie and Sarah stare each other over their glasses. Then Eddie looks away. Sar proposes a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To you, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They touch glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter brings the check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie nods and drinks down the last of his brandy as the  waiter leaves. Sarah sees that Eddie seems somber, preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. (looks at the check) Want another drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I, uh, I'll be leaving town  for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) For how long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A week? A year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More like a week. Look, I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Let's go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up her purse and gloves and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining heavily. Sarah emerges from the building an leans wearily against the awning. Eddie, having hurriedly paid the bill, follows after her. He catches up with Sara taking her by the arm, and stepping out into the street t hail a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She angrily breaks away from him and walks out into the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want to walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (running after her) Come here. Come on, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie grabs Sarah and starts to pull her back under the  awning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and the two of them enter, thoroughly dren

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get some dry things on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks to a chair, limping noticeably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to know where I'm  going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (collapses into a  chair) Yes, I want to know what for. But I  don't want to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits) I'm going to Kentucky. To Louisville.  With a friend. Try to make some money.  I need it, the money. I'll be leaving  early in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, grow up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, I'm going to Kentucky to play  pool, with a guy by the name of  Findley. Now, I need the action and  I need the money. I told you I'd be  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were going to come back you  wouldn't have taken me out tonight.  You wouldn't have bought this dress.  You're hustling me, Eddie. You've  never stopped hustling me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I never hustled you. Even when  I thought I was. You know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do? Just sit  here and wait? Faithful little Sarah.  Pull the shades down and sit. When  you feel like coming back, you'll  come back. And you'll love me. And  then you'll go away again. Is that  your idea of love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got no idea of love. And neither  have you. I mean, neither one of us  would know what it was if we saw it  coming down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd know it, Eddie. I'd know. For  God's sakes, what are you trying to  do to me? I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what's your idea of love?  Chains?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (long pause) I made you up, didn't I, Eddie? You  weren't real. I made you up, like  everything else. There was no car  crash, Eddie. When I was five, I had  polio. I was never an actress. The  rich old man is my father. He walked  out on us when I was seven. He sends  me a check every month. That's how  he buys his way out of my life. The  men I've known... after they left,  I'd say they weren't real, I made  them up. But you, Eddie. I wanted  you to be real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches across and pulls her to him, burying his face her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so scared, Eddie... I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert Gordon leans on the hood of a cab. His face drops wh he sees Eddie and Sarah walking toward him. Eddie cares t suitcases and his leather cue case. He sets the suitcases the curb and the cab driver moves to take them. Courteous Bert opens the door of the taxi for Eddie and Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah Packard... Bert Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Packard. How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah eyes Bert distrustfully and starts to get in the ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, Sarah, and Bert squeeze through the door of the tr compartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a redcap, off  luggage) That brown one's mine. It goes in  drawing room A, huh? Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The redcap exits, carrying the luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to redcap, off  compartment door) I got it, I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie shuts the door. Bert and Sarah sit across from each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you going to be comfortable  enough there, Miss... ah... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly) Packard. Sarah Packard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It always takes me a little while to  get a name fixed in my mind. Are you  sure you don't want anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, uh, you ever been to Louisville  during Derby week, Miss, ah, Packard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been to Louisville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of action. Lots of money. (to Eddie, seated  beside him) Lots of class. You'll see some of  the best-dressed and most beautiful  women in the world at the races.  Knock your eye out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kentucky-bound train rolls down the track. Bert and E finish their breakfast coffee in the dining room. Sarah i in the washroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Findley is a very rich man.  Grandfather left him twenty per cent  of a tobacco company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? And he -- he hustles pool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles) He's a gentleman. Gentleman gambler.  He gets his kicks playing with  hustlers. He's got an old Southern  mansion with a pool table in the  basement, drinks eight-year-old  bourbon, smokes cork-tipped  cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How good is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Never saw him play.  They say he's one of the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah makes her way down the aisle and joins them at the  table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly) I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon as I finish my coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands there, lips pursed, absorbing the insult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bert) You must have a lot of confidence in  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't. But I got confidence in  Findley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Means I got confidence that he's a  loser. All the way a loser. You happen  to be about only one-half loser --  the other half, winner. (off his coffee) I'm finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert gets up and reaches in his pocket for his billfold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. When you play for me, I pick  up all the tabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Sarah just stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are at a table, sipping drinks. Bert shuffles a deck cards as he talks. Eddie, like a schoolboy, listens inten Sarah sits apart, watching them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats knew the game was in the clutch,  knew he had to do something to stop  ya. He played it smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I played that game, Bert. In my head  I played it a thousand times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play it again. Learn something. (laughs, to Sarah) Fats went in the john, see? Washed  his face, cleaned his fingernails,  made his mind a blank, combed his  hair, came back all ready to go. (to Eddie) You were through. You saw him, you  saw how he looked. Clean, all set to  start all over again. Hold tight and  push hard. You know what you were  doing? You were waitin' to get beat.  Flattened out on your butt, swimmin'  around in glory. And whisky. Probably  deciding how you could lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you know so much? How do  you know what Eddie was thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Been there myself. We've all  been there, haven't we, Miss Packard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie glances at Sarah who stares mutely at Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a cigarette) Got a match, Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie reaches across to light Bert's cigarette with the  lighter Sarah gave him. Bert's own lighter is on the tabl before him. Sarah sees it, picks it up, and sparks it int flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't your lighter work, Mr. Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling politely) Oh, I forgot all about it. (to Eddie, who still  holds the flame) How's the hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I'd hate to think I was putting  my money on a cripple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Hey, whaddya say something like that  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Eddie. I'm sure Mr.  Gordon meant no offense. It was a  figure of speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Miss Packard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a fact is a fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a smart girl, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert goes back to shuffling his deck of cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lobby is thronged with gamblers and their women,  sportsmen, tourists, all there for the Derby. A jazz comb can be heard over the din of their voices. Eddie, looking excited, leads Sarah through the crowd. Behind them is Be his face now shaded by dark glasses, following a bellhop the main desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right this way, Mr. Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He forces his way through some people to get to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are, Mr. Gordon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suite fifty-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I-I wired ahead for two suites  adjoining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I do. I want two suites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry, Mr. Gordon. We're  filled up. This is Derby week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert displays a neatly folded wad of money in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, son, you've got it all wrong.  You must have gotten my wire. Look  through your reservations, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (artfully accepts  cash bribe) I'll see what I can do... You were  right, Mr. Gordon. I mislaid your  wire. Uh, two adjoining suites?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie laughs and moves toward the open door leading to th billiard rooms. His face glows as he watches the flow of moving in and out of the crowded room, and hears the soun of clicking pool balls. He tucks his cue case under his a and turns to Bert and Sarah who join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bert) You know, that's real sweet music in  there. You can almost smell the action  and the money. You know, I can feel  it right down in the bottom of my  shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Come on, let's go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before they can head to their rooms, a small, neatly groo man approaches Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his hand  warmly) Hey, Billy, how are ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast Eddie. I didn't know you were  here. Everybody's here. It's like a  hustler's convention. The Whetstone  Kid, Johnny Jumbo. C'mon in. The  guys'll be glad to see you. C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) What room are you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be up later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah turns toward the elevators, with Bert behind her,  jiggling his keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bellboy unlocks the door and Sarah enters. The doors the other suite are open. As she catches sight of Bert  arranging things with the bellboy she closes one door. Th bellboy leaves as she moves to close the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wait a minute, Miss Packard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're neighbors now. You can call me  Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes to the door, holding it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we need words?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think we do. We could try to  cut each other up. But that would be  bad for everybody. Bad for me, bad  for you. And worst of all, be bad  for Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what's good for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For whom and for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what makes the world go round.  For money, and for glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't answer my first question.  For whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Today for me, tomorrow  for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there's no tomorrow. Not with  you. You own all the tomorrows because  you buy them today, and you buy cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Well, nobody has to sell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns back to her,  savagely) Listen, Miss Ladybird, you're here  on a rain check and I know it. You're  hanging on by your nails. You let  that glory whistle blow loud and  clear for Eddie and you're a wreck  on a railroad track. You're a horse  that finished last. So don't make  trouble, Miss Ladybird. Live and let  live. While you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause as he glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make it up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back into his room. She closes the door and leans against it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screams are heard as the horses jerk out of the starting  gate to begin their runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie cashes in a winning ticket

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the cashier) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie moves through the ornate racetrack bar to join Sara at a table. Sarah has been drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Where's Bert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went off someplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that old lovin' horse paid  twenty-two forty. (counts his money) Let's see... two hundred I won from  the jockey last night. And today at  the track... I got five hundred and  forty bucks. (folds it up) Here, you hold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes it) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she puts the money in her purse, Bert sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Findley's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there by the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Findley, studying his program and holding a drink his hand. He is tall and refined, with a pale, debauched, yet oddly youthful face that some men of forty or more sometimes ha A cork-tipped cigarette dangles from his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you gonna go over and talk to  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. Sit tight. He'll be over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Findley spots Bert, takes a long drag on his cigarette, a saunters toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) Are you ready for another?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert points to Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no more for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joins them, speaks  in a soft Southern  drawl, to Bert) Well, hello. Haven't seen you in a  long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hello. Haven't been here for a  long time. (makes introductions) Ah, Miss Packard, Eddie Felson...  James...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert snaps his fingers, pretending to forget Findley's na

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Findley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I you. (shakes Eddie's hand) I think I've heard about you, Mr.  Felson. You play pocket billiards,  don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along) Now and then. Why, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little, although I'm afraid I  generally lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So does Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I win sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smugly) I'll bet you do, Mr. Felson. I'll  just bet you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert, I believe Mr. Felson's making  a proposition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Felson, maybe you could  come out to my place some evening.  We could play a few games of  billiards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very direct, Mr. Felson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to come out tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having some people over for drinks  right after the races. Why don't you  all come over? Then about nine, ten  o'clock we can play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods to them all, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind I think I'll stay  at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her voice slurred) I'm a little tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, there'll be a lot of laughs.  Findley's parties are famous. He  invites everybody from top to bottom,  from high society to every tout,  hustler, and tramp in town. That's  another way he has of gettin' his  kicks. It excites him to be around  what he calls the criminal type.  Some men are like that. (beat) Some women too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah gives Bert a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera tilts upward from a Dixieland combo blaring ou bouncy tune to find Sarah, descending the stairs, looking at the party below. Holding the rail with one hand, and a champagne glass in the other, she maneuvers her way down steps. She stops a waitress on the way upstairs and excha her glass for a new one. We follow her unsteady, doll-lik descent. She moves slowly, dreamily past the combo; past  Eddie, who is cornered by a chic blonde in a low-cut dres past Findley, alone with his drink, observing his guests; past the bleary-eyed couples on the dance floor, until sh comes to the bar. Bert is there too, his head bobbing to the Dixie beat, hi eyes running over her body so plainly covered by a cotton print dress. Spinning away from him, she takes her glass goes to a corner of the room. Bert walks casually to her  side. He leans over and whispers something in her ear. He face hardens. Angrily she turns and throws her champagne his face and smashes her glass on the floor. Then she sta to cry and starts to fall, but Bert holds her up by the  shoulders. The music stops. The dance couples strain to g a look at what has happened. Eddie shoves through the gawking crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. She had a little too  much to drink, that's all. Forget  it. (to Sarah) Go upstairs and sleep it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie tries to take her in his arms, but she beats on his chest, sobbing, unable to make words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, c'mon. Cut it out! Do what he  says. Come on upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie drags her limp, trembling body across the dance flo to the stairs. Bert watches them go, wiping the champagne off his coat lapels. The music starts up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Negro maid sits patiently in the room, watching over Sa and the coats that Sarah is lying on. A woman enters and, disgusted, pushes Sarah off her fur coat. Eddie appears i the doorway. The woman takes her coat and leaves. Eddie l at Sarah for a moment, then turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Findley, drink and cork-tipped cigarette in hand, escorts Bert and Eddie down the stairs to his game room. It is a  beautifully appointed salon, wood-paneled, filled with pl divans and decorated with terra cotta Roman statuary. In center of the room is the billiard table, now covered by cloth. Findley goes to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gentlemen care for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steps briskly into  the room) No, none for me. Come on, let's play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By all means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie eagerly pulls back the cloth that covers the table. But it's not a pool table -- it's a billiard table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we came here to play pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't play pool, Mr. Felson. I  play billiards. My house, my game.  You don't have to play if you don't  want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Bert. Let me play him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Findley) How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we'll start small... a hundred  dollars a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eddie) You ever played billiards before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hustlin' me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure Mr. Felson knows what he's  doing. Certainly you can afford a  hundred dollars to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie finishes uncovering the table. Bert takes a seat.  Findley has a mischievous look on his face as he brings o a cloth bag and pours out the three billiard balls on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie shoots. His red ball ricochets off the shoulder and returns to kiss the third ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful shot, Felson. Beautiful.  You've played billiards before, Mr.  Felson. Ah, you gentlemen sure you  don't care for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, nothing for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Findley steps up to the bar, leaving Bert and Eddie alone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bert) How do we stand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bout even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do I raise the bet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert, if that's his best game, I can  beat him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Level with me, Eddie. You ever play  billiards before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference? You got a  pool cue, balls on the table. All  you gotta do is get the feel of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returns with a fresh  drink) Like to raise the stakes, Mr. Felson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bert) Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, about five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eddie) Do you really think you can beat  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he thinks he can beat me,  Bert. He wouldn't be playing me if  he didn't. Right, Felson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask him can he beat you. I  already know he can beat you. I asked  him will he? With Eddie, that's two  different things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can beat him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Findley points to a statue on a table behind the couch. I is a figure of Pan, with horns sticking up through his cu head, and the legs of a goat extending down below his wai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you noticed, Bert? This fellow  here bears a striking resemblance to  you. It seems as though you might  have modeled for the artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) It's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Findley completes a shot, then lays his cue gently on the table and goes to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark that one up too, Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, his coat off, rubs his hand nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll beat him the next game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toying with his  billfold) How're the hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, rack up your cue. We're leavin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That seems a shame. The night is  young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night is two thousand dollars  old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bert. Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said we're leavin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert turns his back on Eddie and joins Findley at the bar Eddie stands helplessly for a moment. Findley pours a dri as Eddie approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can beat him, Bert. Now he suckered  me 'cause he knows how to hustle. I  didn't think he did. But I can outplay  him. I can beat him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you, Eddie. I think  you're still a loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then. I'll play him with  my own money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches in his pocket, then remembers that he gave his money to Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bounds up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bursts into the room, goes past Sarah, stretched out o the bed, and takes the money out of her purse. She is fac away from him but her eyes are open. She listens to him a he shuts the door loudly on his way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie leaps down the stairs, two at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, c'mon. Let's play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert eyes Eddie with controlled rage as the two get ready play again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game has just ended as Sarah quietly descends the stair She stands at the rail, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is. I'm broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, that's unfortunate, Mr. Felson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For who, Mr. Findley? ...Bert, he  only beat me by one point. Now, you  can't get off me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bank is closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert sits with his shoes up on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't get off me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know when to quit. You don't. Win  or lose, you don't know when to quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (down on one knee) What do you want me to do, huh? What  do you want me to do? Just say it  and you got it but PLEASE don't get  off me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the stairs) Don't beg him, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie turns and sees her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on back to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Eddie, don't beg him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you go on back to the hotel?  Take a cab, go on back to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't all of this come through to  you, Eddie? Doesn't any of this mean  anything to you? That man, this place,  the people. They wear masks, Eddie.  And underneath the masks they're  perverted, twisted, crippled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are shut tight; his balled-up fists rub against temples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving to him) Don't wear a mask, Eddie. You don't  have to. (points to Bert) That's Turk, Eddie, the man who broke  your thumbs. Only he's not going to  break your thumbs. He'll break your  heart, your guts. And for the same  reason -- 'cause he hates you, 'cause  of what you are. 'Cause of what you  have and he hasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises) Would you get off my back, Sarah?  Once and for all, will you get out,  will you GET OFF MY BACK?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead and play him, Eddie. Play  him for a thousand dollars a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunned Eddie moves to the billiard table. Defeated, Sa turns and goes up the stairs. The men return to the table continue their game. Bert, deeply satisfied, puts on his coat and sits to watc the action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shaken Findley flops into a leather swivel chair. A buc of iced champagne sits on the desk, ready to be emptied.  Findley puffs on his cigarette as he looks at the impatie face of Bert, slouching in the chair across from him. Edd leans against a wall nearby. He is quiet, morose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you take a check, Bert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Findley reaches nervously for the bottle, gulps at his dr Then he unlocks his desk drawer and takes out the money.  Eddie looks on as Findley gives the money to Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. (to Eddie) Been an interestin' evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a valet) Charles, will you call a cab for  these gentlemen, please. (to Eddie) I'd show you to the door, but I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, yeah. You're tired. (to Bert) And beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You must come again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie moves to leave. Findley and Bert watch him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie waits for Bert to come down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's your share. Three thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab's waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tips him) Oh, yeah. Here. Thanks... C'mon,  Eddie, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got time, Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to tell her for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta be hard, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie abruptly turns and walks out of the house. Bert wat him for a moment then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert enters his suite, removes his overcoat, then looks a the door that divides his room from Sarah's. He seems  hesitant, unsure of himself. He pours himself a drink and downs it in one gulp, walks to the door, listens, and ope it himself without knocking. Sarah is there, seated priml on the bed. There is a drink in her hand, and a suitcase  beside her on the bed. Bert enters her suite and confront her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah's voice is subdued, controlled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a little while. That's what you  want, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what Eddie wants. He, uh, told  me to give you some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands over her, pulling a wad of bills from his pocke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it on the bed. That's the way  it's done, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tossing it there) That's the way it's done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the way you're looking at me, is  that the way you look at a man you've  just beaten? As if you'd just taken  his money, and now all you want is...  his pride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I want's the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure, just the money, and the  aristocratic pleasure of seeing him  fall apart. You're a Roman, Bert.  You have to win them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks her up and tries to kiss her but she is cold and limp in his arms, so he lets go and she drops back on the bed. Then he turns and walks back into his room. She wait for a moment. Then she takes a cigarette out of a pack, g up, and goes into his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door) You got a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bathroom mirror we see Bert asleep on his bed. The sheets are rumpled and tossed about. Then we see Sarah, i her slip, enter the bathroom and shut the door. She takes out her lipstick and scrawls across the image of herself the glass "Perverted, twisted, crippled." She underlines word "crippled."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie is just getting back. He walks through the lobby,  ignoring the uniformed policeman standing nearby, and sto at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me my key, please. Room fifty- seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The concierge stares dumbly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, c'mon, give me my key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The concierge hands it to him. Eddie walks quickly toward the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters, sees the money on Sarah's bed, puts down his c case, and turns to see a crowd in the adjoining room. Ber laying in bed, talks to a plainclothesman who stands over him, taking notes. A photographer with a flash camera sta by the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, let's go over this again. You  say you were in the other room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she closed the door. I told you  she closed the door. I was in the  other room. She closed the door,  went in there, maybe, I don't know,  ten minutes, five minutes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert stops when he sees Eddie through the open door. A  uniformed policeman bars Eddie's entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the policeman) Hey. Let him come in, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie comes in. He looks at the detectives around Bert's  bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photographer's bulb flashes as he takes a picture of bathroom. Eddie pushes by the photographer, then stops as he sees  Sarah's body laid out on the tiled floor. He drops to his knees beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie reaches out to touch her, then pulls back his hand. Bert appears at the bathroom door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie? She come in here, Eddie. She  asked me for a drink. I give her  one. We had a few more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes closed, he writhes as he listens to Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, she came in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly he uncoils and lunges at Bert, grasping him by t throat and pushing him back. A policeman untangles them, Eddie breaks free. We hear Bert scream as he squirms alon the floor trying to avoid Eddie's fists.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Minnesota Fats sits in his chair, engrossed in the aftern paper. Big John is at a pool table, trying out a few shot Bert, in dark glasses, stands near the cashier's cage,  chucking dice into a leather shaker. The noise of the dice echoes in the slow, late afternoon  gloom of Ames. When Bert sees Eddie push open the glass doors, he draws  himself up fearfully like a turtle, and motions with his  eyes to his men for protection. Eddie, his cue case tucke under his arm, walks straight toward him. He stops, stare at him for a moment, then turns and walks over to Minneso Fats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to play pool, Fats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a glance at  Bert) That's good, Eddie. For how much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You name it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousand dollars a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make it three thousand dollars  a game, Fats. C'mon, three thousand  dollars. That's my bankroll, my life's  savings. (beat) What's the matter, Fats? All you  gotta do is beat me the first game  and I'm on my way back to Oakland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats rises, ready to play. Eddie starts to screw his cue  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on me, Bert. I can't lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to join Fats at the table. The balls are already racked and ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie collects their stake money and prepares to toss th coin. Preacher, Big John draw up their chairs around the table. Bert also takes a seat, but far away, near the coat rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie taps Fats on the lapel. It's his break. Sausage se the cue ball down the table and the game begins at once.  Fats makes a good break, leaving the cue ball teetering o the far corner pocket. He looks up at Eddie, and steps ba Eddie looks at the lineup of the balls. Then he sets down his cue and walks over to the washroom. He glances at Ber as he sprinkles the powder on his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How shall I play that one, Bert?  Play it safe? That's the way you  always told me to play it, safe,  play the percentage. Well, here we  go... fast and loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and snatches up his cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One ball, corner pocket. (chalks his cue, lines  up his shot) Yeah, percentage players die broke  too, don't they, Bert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rams a bank shot into the pack. The one ball rolls in, while others scatter about the table. The crowd applauds. Eddie moves swiftly to his next shot. As he plays, he tal to Bert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I lose? Twelve ball. (shot goes in) I mean, how can I lose? Because you  were right, Bert. I mean, it's not  enough that you just have talent.  You gotta have character too. Four  ball. (shot goes in, a pause) Yeah and I sure got character now. I  picked it up in a hotel room in  Louisville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert and Fats exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from his seat) Shoot pool, Fast Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm shootin' pool, Fats. When I miss  you can shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie returns to his game and Fats waits for his turn, pu steadily on his cigarette. Bert shifts uneasily in his ch and we hear the pool balls knock together, then slowly ro down the track through the belly of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five ball. (shot goes in) ...Fourteen ball. (shot goes in) ...Four ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot goes in. Eddie looks significantly at Fats who l his eyes and puffs on his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The balls are racked. Eddie sinks shots right and left -- some tricky, some not. Bert and Fats exchange uneasy look Eddie circles the table like a hawk. Then, Fats is up; hi jacket is off, his tie is pulled loose. He makes a shot,  chalks his cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hard shot and he misses. Eddie moves to take his s ignoring Fats altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirteen ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert looks on. But Eddie is shooting pool now, making all his shots quickly and accurately. A depressed Fats watche him shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock over the door reads six o'clock. Fats is still his seat. He has a drink in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I quit, Eddie. I can't beat you.  Willie, give him the stakes. (rises, to Bert) You got yourself a pool player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, as he counts  his money) Preacher, gimme my coat, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie slips into the jacket, helped by Preacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie?... (loses it) YOU OWE ME MONEY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) And just how do you figure that,  Bert? What do you figure I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Louisville it was seventy-five  per cent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here it's half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I don't pay ya, Bert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) You don't pay me? You gonna get your  thumbs broken. (stands up and paces) And your fingers. And if I want them  to, your right arm in three or four  places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better pay him, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie unscrews his cue, thinking it over. Bert's bodyguar stand around, waiting for the word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you figure you're still my manager,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a businessman, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you got a lot of games lined  up for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're gonna make a lotta money  together, from now on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty per cent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it don't have to be fifty. It  can be thirty... twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We really stuck the knife in her,  didn't we, Bert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) Aaaahhhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, we really gave it to her good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it didn't happen in Louisville,  it'd happened someplace else. If it  didn't happen now, it'd happen six  months from now. That's the kinda  dame she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we twisted it, didn't we, Bert?  Course, maybe that doesn't stick in  your throat cause you spit it out  just like you spit out everything  else. But it sticks in mine. I loved  her, Bert. I traded her in on a pool  game. But that wouldn't mean anything  to you. Because who did you ever  care about? Just win, win, you said,  win, that's the important thing. You  don't know what winnin' is, Bert.  You're a loser. 'Cause you're dead  inside, and you can't live unless  you make everything else dead around  ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats listens, his head bowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too high, Bert. Price is too high.  Because if I take it, she never lived,  she never died. And we both know  that's not true, Bert, don't we,  huh? She lived, she died. Boy, you  better... You tell your boys they  better kill me, Bert. They better go  all the way with me. Because if they  just bust me up, I'll put all those  pieces back together again, and so  help me, so help me God, Bert... I'm  gonna come back here and I'm gonna  kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert's men start to move forward but he stops them with a gesture of his hand. He tries to smile. A friendly smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie puts away his cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only, uh, don't ever walk into a big- time pool hall again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie just stares at Bert, then looks over at the downcas face of Minnesota Fats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fat man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats looks up at Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you shoot a great game of pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (saluting him with  his glass of whisky) So do you, Fast Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie takes his cue case and heads for the door. He stops for a moment, looks around at the rows of empty tables, a goes out. Then Ames returns to normal. Fats puts on his c Henry sweeps up. And Bert takes his seat again on his thr overlooking Ames, sipping his glass of milk.
